element.name: 30 A Walk in the Garden-War Hill Circuit by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/3.5)
element.long-description:
Visit The Geocaching Ireland discussion forum HERE
My Love comes down from the mountain
Through the mists of dawn;
I look, and the star of the morning
From the sky is gone.
My love comes down from the mountain,
At dawn, dewy-sweet;
Did you step from the star to the mountain,
O little white feet?
O whence came your twining tresses
And your shining eyes,
But out of the gold of the morning
And the blue of the skies?
The misty morning is burning
In the sun’s red fire,
And the heart in my breast is burning
And lost in desire.
I follow you into the valley
But no word can I say;
To the East or the West I will follow
Till the dusk of my day.
(Thomas Boyd)
A good hike on some of the most popular walking routes in the whole of the Garden County. The trek shown on the illustration above is approx 16K in length with a total ascent of just over 1000m. A fair section of the Wicklow Way is included but also some rougher and perhaps more interesting terrain.
The route described above takes you from Crone car park at N53 09.897 W006 13.104 and rises toward Maulin using the little white waymarking signs pinned to the trees (red for coming back down). These are quite enough to get you to Stage 1 but I am also including reference coordinates here to make it more clear. Following the forest track upward to N53 09.865 W006 13.169 you will see a smaller track on the right heading more directly upward. Follow this to N53 09.741 W006 13.290 where you should turn right and walk to N53 09.766 W006 13.402. Here you turn left and walk to N53 09.707 W006 13.463 and turn right. Then at N53 09.709 W006 13.512 keep left and then straight on at N53 09.725 W006 13.607.
By now you should be able to continue the zig zags upwards by following the signs and they will lead you to Stage 1 at the coordinates at the top of the page.
Here you will find 3 numbers which you should call ABC.
From here you should have climbed a stile and be heading out on to the mountains. Soon you will have to cross some rough ground to gain the bog track that will take you along the ridge to Stage 2.
At N53 09.337 W006 15.129 you will find the second set of 3 numbers. Call these DEF. Look for a raised tuft of heather and please do not remove the item.
The final cache coordinates near the summit of War Hill will then be N53 08.ABC W006 15.DEF.
To get there from Stage Two I strongly recommend that you head in the direction of the source of the Dargle at N53 09.015 W006 16.255. This would be particularly useful during Summer time when the heather and ferns can grow thick and high. This will keep you on high enough ground to make your ascent of War Hill that much easier.
On the illustration above you will also see a number of other caches that can be reached by making a very pleasant circular walk back to Crone using Djouce and the Wicklow Way to get there.
From Mountain Views:
War Hill Mountain Wicklow County Cnoc an Bhairr A name in Irish (Language) (Ir. Cnoc an Bhairr [PNCW*], 'hill of the summit') Height: 686 metres OS 1/50k Mapsheet: 56 for top Grid Ref: O16895 11338 Latitude: 53.140026 Longitude: -6.253961 ITM: 716818 711369 Prominence: 71m Isolation: 1.4km Rating graphic. Price's suggested Irish derivation for War Hill, whilst possible, seems rather tautological and is not backed up by any Irish attestations. Barr is itself a common term denoting a hill and is usually the first element in names, e.g. Barr Trí gCom (Baurtregaum), Barr na Coilleadh (Barnakillew), etc. Also "hill of the top" seems a strange way to describe War Hill, since it's really only a lower outlier of Djouce. An alternative is that the name was created in English, and this is supported by a reference to a battle on War Hill in a letter written on 15th December 1838 by Eugene O'Curry. “In the Townland of Lackandarragh in the Powerscourt Parish they shew a place called the Churchyard, but it does not retain the least vestige of either a church or churchyard. Some say that it was the place of sepulture of persons killed in a battle fought between the English troops and the O’Tooles some three hundred years ago. This battle was fought on War Hill, immediately overhanging this Churchyard, on the opposite side of the river.” Of course, one would expect these events to give rise to "Battle Hill", rather than "War Hill", so this suggestion must also be considered tentative. War Hill is the 129th highest summit in Ireland.
Maulin:
Maulin Mountain Wicklow County Málainn A name in Irish (Language) (Ir. Málainn [PNCW], possibly 'high or sloping ground') Height: 570 metres OS 1/50k Mapsheet: 56 for top Grid Ref: O18437 13106 Latitude: 53.155564 Longitude: -6.230278 ITM: 718360 713136 Prominence: 70m Isolation: 2.3km Rating graphic. Málainn is rare element of obscure origin and meaning, occurring in a handul of place-names scattered throughout the country. For origin of name, see articles by Paul Tempan: "The Element Málainn in Place-names" in the Kerry Magazine, No. 18, 2008 (15-16) and "An Eilimint Málainn i Logainmneacha" in the Donegal Annual 2006 (218-19). There are references in early Irish texts to Málu, site of a battle in Leinster. This mountain has been proposed as an identification by Eoin MacNeill (JRSAI lxv, 14), but this is far from certain. Maulin is the 328th highest summit in Ireland. Our data has reached 76% of the goal for this summit. (Details)
Do not start the trek without all the proper mountain rain gear, waterproof boots and the guidance material, compass, map, GPSr with mapping etc.
Please note that all parts of this cache are hiked at your own risk. The cache owner takes no responsibility of any sort for any reason including accidents or mishaps.
Please be aware that cars parked in areas close to walking trails are vulnerable and they can be vandalised or stolen. Unfortunately this is an ongoing problem which is extremely difficult to solve, so there is a risk involved.
Please observe the country code to the best of your ability. Local landowners often generously allow access to upland areas across or through parts of their private property. Please, please be conscious of this and return the courtesy by keeping all gates closed, immediately and not on your way back!. Please use the gates where appropriate but if you have to climb over them then use the hinged side ONLY.
Please do not cause any damage of any sort to fences or barriers along the way.

PK25EKH - Garden 30 Crone Car Park
N 53° 09.897 W 006° 13.104
R125EKH - Garden 30 Ref 1 Right A
N 53° 09.865 W 006° 13.169
R225EKH - Garden 30 Ref 2 Right B
N 53° 09.741 W 006° 13.290
R325EKH - Garden 30 Ref 3 Left A
N 53° 09.766 W 006° 13.402
R425EKH - Garden 30 Ref 4 Right C
N 53° 09.707 W 006° 13.463
R525EKH - Garden 30 Ref 5 Left B
N 53° 09.709 W 006° 13.512
R625EKH - Garden 30 Ref 6 Straight
N 53° 09.725 W 006° 13.607
R725EKH - Garden 30 Ref 7 Source of Dargle

element.url-name: 30 A Walk in the Garden-War Hill Circuit

ul.li:
2010-06-12T21:13:08Z : Needs Maintenance by daraconn
The waypoint for Stage 2 is wrong by 1 minute - it says 6W14 instead of 6W15. The co-ordinates in the text of the cache description are correct.

2010-06-12T19:00:00Z : Found it by daraconn
Followed the circular route suggested which made for a nice long walk with three caches that I hadn't found before. Much of the route I had entirely to myself and the dog, an agreeable feeling of solitude after a stressful week at work.
In the past I've had difficulty finding my way on the north side of Maulin - too many tracks, the discovery map is nearly useless. So I really appreciated all the waypoints, and I was delighted to see that there are now signs on the trees showing the way. After Stage 1 we diverted to the summit of Maulin for a break and a bite. Then checked on the Maulin cache before going on to Stage 2.
There's an error in the waypoint of Stage 2 - it is 1 minute (1.11 km) out. This led to some confusion as the Stage 2 waypoint didn't correspond to the map or to the description. It led to a short excursion into the heather before I realised the error and headed to the right place.
Stage 2 is at the top of a hill which is nameless - it seems unfair as it is a perfectly respectable summit and in fact is higher than Maulin. Second time to visit the location and the Dargle source, having done the WITG (Tonduff) a few weeks ago. Down to the Dargle source - I now realise looking at the map you didn't intend we would track all the way to your reference point 7, but should cross the Dargle about a kilometre further east. This makes sense, as the trek to the source and back is significant extra distance and involves a lot of walking through heather and boggy ground.
Finally up to War Hill, a long steep slog to a lovely rounded summit with the beginnings of a stone cairn. I get the impression it's not often visited. It was my first visit. There are deep dark bog pools on the summit and Shiro plunged in for a swim to cool off.

2010-05-18T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Shailaja
Got to stage one coords with Toffee Man and searched high and low but didn't find any three numbers :S
Decided to leave it for another day and headed for the ones on Maulin and Djouce instead.
Shailaja

2010-05-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by theswerve
Found eventuallywhen i made a horlicks of inputting wrong coords for s2...had me 80 odd mtrs from S1...something wrong i said to self as looking at map its about 1k away...found in the end...like the item at S2...so after Tonduff i went for it and found after a little searching...TFTC...

2010-05-05T19:00:00Z : Found it by didi2206
Well.. that was great but pretty hard going!
Did stage 1 and 2 on Monday - ground was unnaturally dry so do these now before we get our usual drenching!!
Waited til today to do the final stage. Didn't approach from stage 2 though.. went via the Djouce wood car park (I call it the river car park).. we headed due west toward the shoulder of Djouce where there is a kind of trail.. then directly uphill where there was no trail It's so dry up top you can skate down the banks of peat and land in what should be a bog pond but is now just beautiful brown stuffing!!! Great fun.. came down the north side to the Dargle and followed it back to the bridge and headed home. managed to lose a set of car keys ( typical) so if anyone's up there pls keep your eyes open! Thank you for a really enjoyable day to a place I wouldn't normally venture!!

wpt.name: GC25EKH
wpt.desc: 30 A Walk in the Garden-War Hill Circuit by Kili or bust, Multi-cache (2/3.5)
wpt.urlname: 30 A Walk in the Garden-War Hill Circuit

Decided to leave it for another day and headed for the ones on Maulin and Djouce instead.
